gco:CharacterString.#text: EDYSAN (Ecologie et Dynamique des Systèmes Anthropisés) - UMR 7058 - CNRS/UPJV
EDYSAN (Ecologie et Dynamique des Systèmes Anthropisés) - UMR 7058 - CNRS/UPJV
A collection of datasets on forest biodiversity and microclimates in France (2019-2023)

All the data stored in this collection of datasets was collected during the period 2019-2023 within the framework of the project number ANR-19-CE32-0005 entitled "Impacts of Microclimatic Processes on foRest bIodiversity redistributioN under macroclimaTe warming" (IMPRINT) funded by the Agence nationale de la recherche (ANR). The project aims to model forest microclimates at fine spatiotemporal resolution and link it to understory biodiversity data. The different datasets available in that collection contain (i) biodiversity surveys (vascular plants, bryophytes and soil artropods), (ii) in-situ microclimate records (both air and soil temperature near the ground surface), (iii) ground-truth measurements of stand characteristics (maximum height, stem diameter, species identity and status) and (iv) high-resolution airborne LiDAR images, all collected across three deciduous state forests in France (Aigoual, Blois and Mormal). Mormal is a lowland forest dominated by beech (Fagus sylvatica) and/or pedunculate oak (Quercus robur) stands, Blois is a lowland forest dominated by pure sessile oak stands (Quercus petraea), and Aigoual is a mountain forest dominated by pure beech stands. All three are state forests managed by the ONF (Office National des Forêts, i.e. French forest office), mostly as even-aged “high forests”, except for a few coppices in Aigoual as well as some stands not managed for accessibility or conservation reasons.
EDYSAN (Ecologie et Dynamique des Systèmes Anthropisés) - UMR 7058 - CNRS/UPJV
EDYSAN (Ecologie et Dynamique des Systèmes Anthropisés) - UMR 7058 - CNRS/UPJV
Continents, countries, sea regions of the world.
Forêts domaniales de Mormal (Nord, 59), de Blois (Loir-et-Cher, 41) et de l'Aigoual (Gard et Lozère, 30 et 48)
Using airborne LiDAR to map forest microclimate temperature buffering or amplification
Article publié dans Remote Sensing of Environment
Ecological indicator values of understory plants perform poorly to infer forest microclimate temperature
article publié dans Journal of Vegetation Science
Responses of vascular plants and bryophytes to forest microclimate buffering
article en cours de révision, publié comme preprint

This collection of datasets on forest biodiversity and microclimates in France is divided into 5 different sets: (#1) one set for understory vegetation surveys; (#2) one set for soil arthropod surveys; (#3) one set for air and soil temperature records; (#4) one set for forest stand characteristics; and (#5) one set for remote sensing data acquired from airborne LiDAR. Each of these 5 different sets are then divided into 3 subsets: one per forest (Aigoual, Blois and Mormal). Within each forest, a total of 60 plots were initially installed at the onset of the project in 2020. Within a given forest, all 60 plots were placed according to a gradient of stand conditions, ranging from very open stand conditions in young forest stages to very dense and closed-canopy conditions in mature forest stands. Within each plot, we installed microclimate sensors (HOBO loggers) to record air and soil temperature in the understory (set #3). We performed a vegetation survey (vascular plants and bryophytes) (set #1), we installed pitfall traps to survey soil arthropods (set #2) and we described stand characteristics (set #4). In addition to this, in summer 2021, we subcontracted a company for airborne LiDAR data acquisition over each forest (set #5). Hence, the common unit that links all five sets of datasets in that collection is the plot ID.
